text: Increased <extra_id_0> interleukin-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production via a phosphoinositide 3-kinase / <extra_id_0> Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and nuclear factor ?
B - dependent pathway in patients with rheumatoid arthritis
Inflammatory mediators have been recognized as being important in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis ( RA ) .

<extra_id_0> Interleukin (IL)-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is an important regulator of immune and inflammatory responses , including the induction of proinflammatory cytokines and osteoclastic bone resorption .
Evidence for the expression and proinflammatory activity of <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has been demonstrated in RA synovium and in animal models of RA .

Although some cytokines ( <extra_id_0> IL-15 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-23 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) have been reported to regulate <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production , the intracellular signaling pathways that regulate <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production remain unknown .

In the present study , we investigated the role of the phosphoinositide 3-kinase ( PI3K ) / <extra_id_0> Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> pathway in the regulation of <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production in RA .

Peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) from patients with RA ( n = 24 ) were separated , then stimulated with various agents including anti-CD3 , anti - <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> phytohemagglutinin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> PHA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and several inflammatory cytokines and chemokines .
<extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> levels were determined by sandwich enzyme - linked immunosorbent assay and reverse transcription - polymerase chain reaction .

The production of <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was significantly increased in cells treated with anti-CD3 antibody with or without anti - <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> PHA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( P < 0.05 ) .

Among tested cytokines and chemokines , <extra_id_0> IL-15 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> upregulated <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production ( P < 0.05 ) , whereas <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-1beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-18 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or <extra_id_0> transforming growth factor-beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> did not .
<extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was also detected in the PBMC of patients with osteoarthritis , but their expression levels were much lower than those of RA PBMC .

Anti-CD3 antibody activated the PI3K / <extra_id_0> Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> pathway ; activation of this pathway resulted in a pronounced augmentation of nuclear factor kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) DNA - binding activity .

<extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production by activated RA PBMC is completely or partly blocked in the presence of the NF-kappaB inhibitor pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate and the PI3K / <extra_id_0> Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibitor wortmannin and LY294002 , respectively .

However , inhibition of <extra_id_0> activator protein-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> extracellular signal-regulated kinase 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> did not affect <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production .

These results suggest that signal transduction pathways dependent on PI3K / <extra_id_0> Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and NF-kappaB are involved in the overproduction of the key inflammatory cytokine <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in RA .
